11523123211.content:
Tommy began to cry. Despite his mom saying she'd be back in five minutes, he didn't like this place!
Then, Chuckie walked over. "Tommy?" he asked.
"Chuckie!" said Tommy.

Just then, another baby walked up.
"Hi, boys, you're new. I'm Wiseguy."
"That's a weird name," said Chuckie.
"Well, actually the name's William," said the other boy, "But they call me Wiseguy because I'm smart for my age. And this is Morgan, but we call him Crybaby because he cries a lot, Dopporsha who we call Doughboy because he can make anything out of play dough, Belinda who we call Builder because she builds with blocks a lot, and Big Justin, who's mean."

What happens now?
11523123211.title: Chuckie is with him.

115231232111.content:
"You've gotta fit in, so, you need nicknames."

"Cool."
Both boys were impressed. Maybe, this place wouldn't be so bad after all.

115231232111.title: "Wiseguy" nicknames Tommy and Chuckie.

11523123212.content:
Tommy was sitting on the floor of the daycare crying.
However, he stopped when he saw Phil and Lil.
"Tommy!" they said.
"Phil! Lil!" said Tommy.

Just then, a boy came over. "Hi, newbies," he said, "I'm Wiseguy."
"Hi, said Tommy, "I'm Tommy, and these are my friends Philip and Lillian, but you can call 'em Phil and Lil!"
"Who names their son Wiseguy?" said Lil.
"Well, my real name's William," said Wiseguy, "But I'm smart, so I got this nickname. Everyone in this daycare's gots a nickname: we call Morgan here 'Crybaby' because he cries a lot, Dopporsha over there gets called 'Doughboy' as he sculpts things out of play dough, Belinda we call 'Builder' because she loves to build with blocks, and Justin gets called 'Big Justin' because he's big for his age."

"We've already gots nicknames, Philip", said Lillian.
"Yeah," said Phil, "But they're just short versions of our regular names."

What happens now?

11531211.title: Lisa wants to go to the grown up table as well.

115312111.content:
Clyde, Lisa, and Lincoln were in Lincoln's room, talking.
"Well, Lincoln and Lisa, you've come to the right place," he said, "As an only child, I've been at the grownup table my whole life."
"So, do you think you can help us?" said Lincoln.
"Did Napoleon have a Napoleon complex?" replied Clyde.
Lincoln just looked confused.
"That's a grownup table joke," said Clyde, "You don't get it now but you will soon. Now, don't worry, I have a sure-fire program that'll get your family to stop seeing you as kids."
However, Lincoln then saw Clyde sitting on Bun-Bun and said, "Careful-- you're giving Bun-Bun an ouchie."
Lisa sighed and said, "You do realise stuffed animals are impervious to pain, don't you? And by the way, the Napoleon joke is a rhetorical question put in place of the word 'yes' in reference to how he obviously had a Napoleon complex due to the fact that it was named after him."
"Oh," said Lincoln.
"See, you're nearly a grownup already," said Clyde.

The next morning, Lincoln and Lisa were drinking coffee as part of their plan to act like grownups.
Lincoln spat his out all over the older sisters, but Lisa swallowed hers down (although she didn't like the taste any more than Lincoln).
Clyde gave them both a thumbs up.

They then entered the living room reading newspapers, where Lori and Leni were on the couch.
"Hey, guys," said Lincoln, "There's a really interesting new article in here about how kids are maturing faster these days. They say eleven is the new fifteen."
"And four is the new twelve," added Lisa.
Lori and Leni looked confused.
Lincoln then turned on the TV to a White House press conference.
"Ooh, the House is debating the new highways bill," said Lincoln.
"This should be fascinating," added Lisa.
"Are you two feeling OK?" asked Lori.
"Us?" said Lincoln, "Never felt better, though our backs are a little stiff. Getting older ain't easy. Am I right, ladies?"
Lori and Leni shrugged.

Lincoln then tried to help the twins share a jump rope by cutting it in half (which made Lisa facepalm) and then they both tried to shave (Lincoln his face, Lisa her legs), but ended up cutting themselves by accident.
However, Clyde thought they were doing well, and decided to give them a lesson in table manners.

"This is the grownup table simulator," he said, referring to cardboard dummies of the older sisters and parents around a table.
"Now," added Clyde, "Show me your salad forks,".
Lisa picked hers up, but Lincoln just took a wild guess.
Clyde blasted an air horn.
"Correct, Lisa, but wrong, Lincoln! That's the *dinner* fork. Now, have some bread."
Lisa picked up some bread.
"Correct," said Clyde.
Lincoln tried to take bread too but he accidentally took some of Lori's.
Clyde blasted the air horn again and said, "Wrong, you just ate Lori's bread!," then added to Lori, "Don't worry, beautiful, I'll share my buns with you."
Lisa cringed and Lincoln blew the air horn to get Clyde's attention.
"So Lynn," said Lincoln to the Lynn dummy, "How about those Republicans."
Clyde blew the air horn and said, "Wrong! Never talk about politics! Again."
"Uh... we can really use some rain?"
Clyde then gave them both some flashcards (although a photo of Lori somehow got in there).

Finally, they were ready, but Clyde had them take one last step: dressing up (Lincoln in a grey suit and Lisa in a fancy red dress).

At dinner, Lincoln and Lisa said in unison, "There comes a time in every kid's life when he or she is ready to put away childish things and make that big leap into the adult world."
"Get to the point, Lincoln and Lisa!" snapped Lori.
"Okay," said Lincoln, "We don't think we should sit at the kiddie table anymore."
"We want to sit at the grownup table with you," said Lisa.
"Well, I think they're ready," said Lynn Sr.
"So do I," said Rita.
"Yes, woo hoo!" said Lincoln, and Lisa did a slight smile.

At the table, Lincoln was bored and didn't like the liver that was served to the older people while the rest of the younger kids had chicken nuggets.
When he tried to tell a joke, he was informed that jokes and singing weren't allowed at the grownup table.
He then chuckled when he caught a glimpse of Lana singing "Beans, Beans, the Magical Fruit."
"Something funny, Lincoln?" asked Lynn Sr.
"Not at this table," replied Lincoln.
Lisa didn't mind any of that, but like Lincoln, she *did* mind not getting dessert. Is that enough to make her want to go back to the kiddie table?
115312111.title: Rather well.

115312211.content:
In a parallel universe, an eleven-year-old Lily was eating at the kiddie table with her four younger sisters and a one-year-old Lincoln.
The twins were poking her in the face with sausages and she said, "In most families, the 'kiddie table' is something you only see at holidays, but in a family as big as mine, it's part of everyday life."
"Hey, Lily, you like seafood?" asked Lana, then opened her mouth full of food and said, "See food? Bleegh!".
Lola then stuck two french fries in her mouth as fangs and said, "Hey, Lucy, I vant to suck your blood!". With that, she sprayed ketchup all over Lily's face and the five younger siblings each dipped a french fry into it.
"For gosh sakes, you guys, cut it out!", she exclaimed, then said, "It's not right. My five older sisters get to sit at the grownup table with Mom and Dad, while I'm stuck here with my four younger sisters and one younger brother."

Lucy then said, "How can you eat that broccoli when you know how much it suffered to get here?"
"Uh, Lucy," said Lily, "Broccoli doesn't feel pain."
"Oh no?" said Lucy, shoving the broccoli in Lily's face, "Listen to the broccoli screaming, Lily, listen to it!".
"Can't I just eat my dinner in peace!?" yelled Lily.
"Did you say, 'peas'?" said Lana, throwing peas at Lily.
The younger siblings then started to have a food fight, while Lily imagined herself being at the grownup table with her older sisters and parents all dressed in their finery.
She expressed her wishes to go to the grownup table, but everyone just scoffed.
"You'll see!," she said, "I'm gonna make it to the grownup table and leave all you children behind!".

She got advice from....

115312212.content:
In a parallel universe, an eleven-year-old Lana was sitting at the kiddie table with Lucy, Lily, Lisa, Lola, and a six-year-old Lincoln.
Lola and Lincoln (who were now twins) were poking her in the head with sausages.
"I said cut it out!", said Lana, "In most families, the 'kiddie table' is something you only see at holidays, but in a family as big as mine, it's part of everyday life."
"Do you like seafood, Lana?" asked Lincoln, then opened his mouth and said, "See food- bleeeh!".
Lana chuckled (despite being eleven, she still had gross habits), but then Lola stuck two french fries in her mouth as fangs and said, "Hey, Lucy, I vant to suck your blood!" and sprayed ketchup at Lana's face.
Lana's younger siblings dipped their fries in it and Lana said, "It's not right. My five older sisters get to sit at the grownup table with Mom and Dad, while I'm stuck here with my four younger sisters and one younger brother."

"How can you eat that broccoli when you know how much it's suffered to get here?", said Lucy.
"Uh, Lucy, broccoli doesn't feel pain," said Lana.
"Oh, no?", said Lucy, shoving the broccoli in Lana's face, "Listen to the broccoli screaming, Lana, listen to it!"
"Can't I just eat my dinner in peace?!" exclaimed Lana.
"Did you say, 'peas'?!" exclaimed Lincoln and flung peas at Lana.
The others had a food fight, while Lana imagined being at the grownup table.
"That's it!", she said, "I don't belong here! I'm gonna go ask to join the grownup table!"

"Ha!", said Lola.
"Good luck," said Lincoln.
"You really think they're gonna let you?" said Lucy.
"You'll see!," said Lana, "I'm gonna make it to the grownup table and leave all you children behind."

info.brief_description: Change a moment of an episode
info.description:
Each category is broken down into two sections
Alter = change anything i.e: TG TF AR AP etc
What if = change the story line i.e: Johnny Test stuck as a dog

So any series Live Action, Cartoon or Anime, you can do anything you want however there’s two exceptions

1) Sex is fine but don’t get to graphic
2) NO Vore
